summary_points: 1. IFF anticipates a $1.0 billion to $1.5 billion goodwill impairment charge in Q1 2025, resulting from a Nourish segment restructuring.
2.  IFF's 2024 net income significantly improved to $243 million, compared to a $2,567 million net loss in 2023.
3.  IFF is implementing a new supply chain financing program in 2025 for US-based suppliers.
1. Blackstone's total revenue for 2024 was $13.2 billion, a 65% year-over-year increase.
2.  A 1% carried interest service fee was implemented for departing participants in Blackstone's carried interest program, effective January 1, 2025.
3.  Blackstone settled an SEC inquiry in January 2025, paying a $12 million penalty.
1. At Hologic Inc.'s Annual Meeting of Stockholders on February 26, 2025, all eight director nominees were elected to the Board for a one-year term.
2.  Shareholders provided advisory approval to replace supermajority voting provisions with a simple majority standard, with 171,853,788 votes for and 30,746,543 votes against.
3.  Ernst & Young LLP was ratified as Hologic's independent registered public accounting firm for the fiscal year ending September 27, 2025.

1. On February 25, 2025, Waste Management, Inc. granted annual incentive awards to its named executive officers, including performance share units (PSUs) and stock options under the Company’s 2023 Stock Incentive Plan.
2.  The number of PSUs granted varied significantly among executives, ranging from 43,636 for the President and CEO to 7,636 for two senior vice presidents.

3.  PSUs vest and pay out based on performance measures (cash flow generation and total shareholder return relative to the S&P 500) by December 31, 2027;  awards range from 0-200% of the targeted amount, and involuntary termination for cause results in immediate forfeiture.
1. Traci Hornfeck resigned as Rollins Inc.'s Chief Accounting Officer and principal accounting officer, effective March 11, 2025.
2.  Kenneth D. Krause, the Company’s Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, will assume the role of principal accounting officer.
3.  Rollins Inc.'s filing indicates no disagreements with Hornfeck regarding the company's financials, internal controls, operations, policies, or practices.
1. Gen Digital Inc. issued $950 million in 6.250% Senior Notes due 2033 on February 28, 2025, using the net proceeds to redeem all outstanding 5.00% Senior Notes due 2025.
2. The 2025 notes, totaling $1.1 billion, were originally issued on February 9, 2017.

3. The new notes are redeemable at any time before April 1, 2028, at a price determined by a formula using the Treasury rate plus 50 basis points, or at 100% of principal plus accrued interest after that date.
1. CoStar Group completed its acquisition of Matterport on February 28, 2025, with each share of Matterport Class A common stock converted into 0.03552 CoStar shares and $2.75 in cash.

2. The exchange ratio for the Matterport acquisition was 0.03552, determined based on the average volume-weighted price of CoStar shares over the 20 trading days ending three trading days prior to the merger's effective time.

3. The press release announcing the merger mentions the combined company's plans to invest further in AI, computer vision, and machine learning to improve property analytics and expand the use of digital twin technologies, targeting a $327 trillion global property asset class.
1. Dayforce's revenue increased 16.3% year-over-year to $1,760 million in 2024.
2.  A 5% workforce reduction is planned, resulting in anticipated restructuring charges of $24 million to $29 million in Q1 2025.
3.  Research and development expenses increased significantly from $92.3 million in 2022 to $123 million in 2024.

1. Louisville Gas and Electric Company (LG&E) and Kentucky Utilities Company (KU) filed an application with the Kentucky Public Service Commission (KPSC) on February 28, 2025, for approval of approximately $3.725 billion in capital expenditures from 2025 to 2031 for new generation and battery storage projects.

2.  The proposed projects include two 645MW natural gas combined cycle units, a 400MW battery storage facility, and a selective catalytic reduction facility, with anticipated in-service dates ranging from 2028 to 2031.
3. The KPSC is expected to rule on the application during the fourth quarter of 2025;  the filing notes that the outcome of the proceedings is uncertain.

1. On February 28, 2025, Ameriprise Financial Inc. issued $750,000,000 in 5.200% Senior Notes due 2035, sold via an underwriting agreement with Goldman Sachs & Co. LLC, Barclays Capital Inc., and Wells Fargo Securities, LLC.
2.  The notes were sold at 99.005% of the principal amount plus accrued interest, resulting in net proceeds of $742,537,500 to Ameriprise after underwriting discounts and before expenses.
3. The filing indicates that the offering of the notes will not cause Ameriprise to become an investment company, but makes no mention of any other specific future impacts or risks.
1. Teleflex plans to spin off its Urology, Acute Care, and OEM businesses into a separate publicly traded company by mid-2026.
2.  A $240 million goodwill impairment charge was recorded in 2024, primarily due to lower than expected UroLift sales.

3. Teleflex is financing the €760 million acquisition of BIOTRONIK's Vascular Intervention business with a $500 million delayed-draw term loan,  amended credit agreements allowing for an additional $550 million borrowing capacity, and existing cash resources.
1. Steel Dynamics' 2024 net sales decreased 7% year-over-year to $17.5 billion, primarily due to metal spread compression.
2.  Steel Dynamics anticipates $358.9 million in purchase obligations due in 2025.
3. The new recycled aluminum flat rolled products mill is expected to begin shipments mid-year 2025, with a projected product mix focused on sustainable beverage packaging (45%).
1. Dollar Tree, Inc. expanded its board of directors from nine to twelve members on February 27, 2025.
2.  Timothy A. Johnson, a newly appointed Dollar Tree director, will retire from Victoria's Secret & Co. in June 2025.
3.  Dollar Tree's amended bylaws, reflecting the increased board size, became effective immediately following the February 27, 2025 appointments.
1. Align Technology completed a $85.8 million acquisition of Cubicure GmbH in 2024.
2.  Align Technology anticipates approximately $100 million in annualized cost savings from its restructuring plan by the end of 2025.
3.  As of January 31, 2025, Align Technology had $297.1 million remaining in its authorized common stock repurchase program, with an additional $225 million planned for repurchase by early May 2025.

1. At Deere & Company's annual meeting on February 26, 2025, a shareholder proposal for a report on racial and gender hiring statistics was rejected by shareholders, with 200,214,274 shares voted against the proposal.

2.  Several other shareholder proposals concerning reports on meritocratic workplaces, corporate financial sustainability, civil rights audits, and charitable giving were also not approved at the February 26, 2025, annual meeting.
3. All director nominees were elected for terms expiring at the 2026 annual meeting, with varying levels of shareholder support ranging from 191,477,516 to 203,763,124 votes in favor.
1. Dmitri Stockton resigned from the Smurfit Westrock plc Board of Directors, effective May 2, 2025.
2.  The company's name changed from Smurfit WestRock plc on June 28, 2024, and from Smurfit WestRock Ltd. on December 26, 2023.
3.  No specific future impacts or risks are mentioned beyond the resignation of a board member.
1. As of February 28, 2025, AES Corp. reported a full-year 2024 net income of $698 million, a significant increase compared to a net loss of $182 million in 2023.
2.  AES Corp. initiated 2025 guidance for Adjusted EBITDA of $2,650 to $2,850 million, and for Adjusted EPS of $2.10 to $2.26.
3.  AES Corp. expects strong growth in renewables Adjusted EBITDA in 2025, driven by completed projects and a backlog of signed PPAs, with 85% expected to be operational by the end of 2027.
1. Edison International projects 5-7% core EPS growth annually from 2025-2028, contingent upon a $38-43 billion infrastructure investment.
2.  Southern California Edison's wildfire liability, potentially reaching $3.9 billion, awaits a final GRC decision expected in 2025.
3.  Edison International's  $38-43 billion electric infrastructure investment plan runs from 2025-2028.
1. Invitation Homes' 2025 acquisition budget increased to $600 million - $900 million, significantly higher than previously projected $600 million - $800 million.
2.  Invitation Homes reported improved January-February 2025 lease rate growth, with renewal rates up to 5.5% and new lease rates improving to -0.8%.
3.  The company plans to partially fund acquisitions by selling $400 million to $600 million of wholly-owned properties in 2025.
1. News Corp repurchased approximately US$642,253,198.21 worth of Class A and Class B shares as of February 27, 2025, under a US$1 billion stock repurchase program.
2. On February 27, 2025,  21,093,270 Class A shares and 10,406,914 Class B shares were repurchased at a highest price of US$30.69 and US$35.25 respectively.
3. News Corp's future stock repurchases are subject to market conditions, the market price of the company's stock, and other factors, with no ASX-listed CDIs to be repurchased.
1. Vistra Corp.'s acquisition of Energy Harbor in March 2024 increased net income by $1.32 billion for the year ended December 31, 2024.
2. A January 2025 fire at the Moss Landing battery energy storage facility is expected to result in a $400 million write-off in Q1 2025.
3.  The EPA's GHG rule, finalized in May 2024 and currently subject to a 60-day legal hold, may significantly impact Vistra's costs starting in 2030.
1. HP's Q1 2025 net earnings decreased by $57 million year-over-year, to $565 million.
2.  As of January 31, 2025, HP identified a material weakness in its internal controls over financial reporting related to software solutions.

3. HP's amended Fiscal 2023 plan (effective February 27, 2025) includes an additional $150 million in restructuring charges, primarily due to increased workforce reductions, bringing the total reduction to between 1,000 and 2,000 employees.

1. Palantir Technologies Inc. appointed Jeffrey Buckley as Chief Accounting Officer, effective March 24, 2025, replacing David Glazer who will return to his role as Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer.

2. Mr. Buckley will receive an annual base salary of $400,000 and a restricted stock unit award covering $3,500,000 worth of Class A common stock, vesting over time contingent upon continued employment.

3.  No family relationships were disclosed between Mr. Buckley and any Palantir directors or executive officers, and no transactions requiring disclosure under Item 404(a) of Regulation S-K were reported.
1. EPAM's year-over-year revenue growth was minimal at 0.8% to $4.73 billion as of December 31, 2024, impacted by factors including the sale of Russian holdings and currency fluctuations.

2.  As of December 31, 2024, EPAM had $78.6 million in cash and cash equivalents held in Ukrainian and Belarusian banks, potentially impacting repatriation due to Belarusian restrictions on dividend distribution until the end of 2025.
3.  EPAM incurred $20.6 million in expenses exceeding its $100 million humanitarian commitment to Ukraine in 2024.
1. FirstEnergy's 2024 earnings decreased 13% year-over-year, totaling a $145 million decline, primarily due to increased ARO liabilities, SEC penalties, and lower revenues.
2.  New tariffs and Maryland legislation (challenged in court) are projected to negatively impact FirstEnergy's future cash flow and profitability by at least $25 million through 2030.
3. FirstEnergy secured $3 billion in funding for transmission infrastructure upgrades through the selection of its proposed Valley Link projects.
1. UnitedHealth Group's 2024 consolidated revenues increased by 8%, despite a $7.1 billion loss from the sale of its Brazil operations.
2.  The Change Healthcare cyberattack in 2024 cost UnitedHealth Group $3.067 billion ($2.2 billion in direct costs and $867 million in estimated business disruption).

3. As of December 31, 2024, UnitedHealth Group had $4 billion in committed healthcare acquisitions pending regulatory approval and $12.7 billion in future revenue expected from remaining performance obligations, with half anticipated within three years.

1. Illinois Tool Works Inc. amended its Euro-denominated credit agreement on February 24, 2025, extending its termination date to February 28, 2027 (with a possible extension to September 15, 2027), lowering the interest rate spread, and updating interest periods.
2. As of February 24, 2025, the company had €750 million outstanding under the amended credit agreement, representing a full drawdown of the available funds.
3. The amendment agreement includes a provision allowing for a single extension of the termination date to September 15, 2027, contingent on no defaults occurring.
1. Corpay secured $5.36 billion in loan commitments in 2024.
2.  Corpay's net income increased by 2.2% year-over-year in 2024 to $1,003.7 million, but recognized a $90 million goodwill impairment loss in October 2024.
3.  Intangible asset amortization is projected to increase significantly from $235 million in 2025 to $967 million by 2029.
1. Synopsys Inc. completed the acquisition of ANSYS, Inc. on February 27, 2025, making ANSYS a wholly-owned subsidiary.
2. ANSYS's audited consolidated balance sheet as of December 31, 2024, shows total assets of $8,051,431,000 and total liabilities and stockholders' equity of the same amount.
3.  Synopsys anticipates incurring $14.3 billion in debt to finance the ANSYS acquisition, potentially adjusted if the number of Synopsys shares issued exceeds 19.9999% of outstanding shares.
